comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See an earlier picture of McDonald and Young Fox. Young Fox is a British boxer and McDonald his manager.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Bain's caption does not identify the man at right.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Another Bain/LOC photo of Ed "Gunboat" Smith, newly posted to Flickr on November 26, 2010:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5208800241/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Dal Hawkins appears to be an ex-boxer by 1914. See boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=10974&cat=boxer NYT of Oct 29, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70D16F73F5A15738... suggests that he had a training facility for boxers "on the Westchester Road."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: boxrec.com/media/index.php/Jimmy_Buckley indicates that a Jimmy Buckley managed Ed Gunboat Smith.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Yes, Buckley stood by Smith on January 1, when he pounded Arthur Pelkey:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4668752209/]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: April 4, 1914 NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10A16F8355D13738... notes that Young Joe Fox would be fighting at the Fairmont "tonight" in the last piece of boxing news in this excerpt.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: It could be the brothers Fox, Wystan. At least he had a boxing brother, Percy, who accompanied him to the States after WW I. See Evening public ledger. (Philadelphia [Pa.]) 1914-1942, February 05, 1919, Night Extra Closing Stock Prices, Image 16 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1919-02-05/ed-...
